text:
POEMS IN ENGLISH - No, 7
Wallace Stevens
"Disillusionment of Ten O'clock"
The houses ere hÂ§unted
Ey white night-gowns.
None are green.
Or purple with green rings,
Or green with purple rings.
Or yellow with blue rings.
None of them are strange.
With socks of lace
And beaded ceintures.
People are not going
To dream of baboons and periwinkles
Only, here and there, an old sailor.
Drunk and asleep in his boots.
Catches tigers
In red weather.
I. A BRIEF PARAPHRASE
The poet says that the lives of the people In the houses are dull and
unimaginative and are as undistinguished and colorless as the nightgowns
they wear. Yet the drunken sailor who has fallen asleep still wearing his
boots has exciting dreams, and is somehow, because of his Imagination and
individuality, more in touch with life than the respectable citizens.
II. THE GLOSSARY:
baboons (n. pi.)
beaded (adj.)
ceintures (n. pi.. Archaic)
disillusionment (n.s.)
haunted (adj.)
here and there (adv. phrase)
nightgowns (n. pi.)
periwinkles (n. pi.)
rings (n. pi)
socks (n. pi.)
large apes
decorated with small pieces of glass
or metal
belts
disappointment, disenchantment
inhabited by ghosts and spirits
in various places
loose garments worn in bed
shellfish similar to snails
circular designs
short stockings
